Author: _luke_w_
Content: I'm getting a couple of hundred klayout DRCs in the standard cell region. They're all `CO.6a (i) Metal1 (< 0.34um) end-of-line overlap contact`. Only other mention I found on this discord was https://discord.com/channels/1361349522684510449/1424739011846471740/1424745841952030860. Any ideas what could be causing that? I'm using 9-track cells if that helps

Author: _luke_w_
Content: I have to confess I've not merged the project template for about a week and a half, so I could be missing some updates

Author: _luke_w_
Content: here is one point it flagged between 33/0 and 34/0 (presumably m1 and contact). 1 box = 20 nm

Author: 246tnt
Content: https://gf180mcu-pdk.readthedocs.io/en/latest/physical_verification/design_manual/drm_07_13.html

Author: 246tnt
Content: I'm trying to understand the rule but ... it's not super clear TBH ðŸ˜…

Author: 246tnt
Content: Can you zoom out a bit ? Does the line "end" there ?

Author: tholin
Content: I know this rule!

Author: tholin
Content: It needs some metal right here

Author: tholin
Content: There is a separate contact overlap minimum for traces that are exactly the minimum-width and at the end of their line.

Author: 246tnt
Content:
Well KLayout seems convinced it does, but I'm not sure it's not an error in the KLayout deck.
For me I see that as falling in the CO.6b case.

Author: tholin
Content: When a trace terminates at a contact, then the edge opposite to where the trace extends is the "end of line"

Author: tholin
Content: In these cases, additional overlap is needed

Author: tholin
Content: Which is only partially true for the example shown here, but it seems its still covered by the rule.

Author: tholin
Content: For now, I suggest adding the affected standard cells to the exclude lists.

Author: 246tnt
Content: OTOH that cell library was made by GF so when there is doubt, I tend to suspect the KLayout deck more.

Author: tholin
Content: Actually, the overlap shown here is *tiny.* I doubt this would pass even magic DRC.

Author: 246tnt
Content: CO.6b rule is specially for that case that says if the overlap is less than 40 nm you can "compensate" by having a bigger overlap on the adjacent sides.

Author: 246tnt
Content: But I agree that excluding the affected cell is the easiest thing to do given the time constraints.
